metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: DSA Insertion Sort Time Complexity
See this page for a general explanation of what time complexity is.
content.html: See this page for a general explanation of what time complexity is.

content.text: Insertion Sort Time Complexity

The worst case scenario for Insertion Sort is if the array is already sorted, but with the highest values first. That is because in such a scenario, every new value must "move through" the whole sorted part of the array.
content.html: The worst case scenario for Insertion Sort is if the array is already sorted, but with the highest values first. That is because in such a scenario, every new value must "move through" the whole sorted part of the array.

content.text: These are the operations that are done by the Insertion Sort algorithm for the first elements:
content.html: These are the operations that are done by the Insertion Sort algorithm for the first elements:

content.text: If we continue this pattern, we get the total number of operations for n n values:
content.html: If we continue this pattern, we get the total number of operations for nn values:
1+2+3+...+(n−1)1+2+3+...+(n−1)

content.text: This is a well known series in mathematics that can be written like this:
content.html: This is a well known series in mathematics that can be written like this:
n(n−1)2=n22−n2n(n−1)2=n22−n2

content.text: For very large n n , the n 2 2 n 2 2 term dominates, so we can simplify by removing the second term n 2 n 2 .
content.html: For very large nn, the n22n22 term dominates, so we can simplify by removing the second term n2n2.

content.text: Using Big O notation, we get this time complexity for the Insertion Sort algorithm:
content.html: Using Big O notation, we get this time complexity for the Insertion Sort algorithm:
O(n22)=O(12⋅n2)=O(n2)––––––––––––––O(n22)=O(12⋅n2)=O(n2)__

content.text: The time complexity can be displayed like this:
content.html: The time complexity can be displayed like this:

content.text: As you can see, the time used by Insertion Sort increases fast when the number of values is n n increased.
content.html: As you can see, the time used by Insertion Sort increases fast when the number of values is nn increased.

content.text: Insertion Sort Simulation
Use the simulation below to see how the theoretical time complexity O ( n 2 ) O ( n 2 ) (red line) compares with the number of operations of actual Insertion Sorts.
content.html: Use the simulation below to see how the theoretical time complexity O(n2)O(n2) (red line) compares with the number of operations of actual Insertion Sorts.

content.text: Set values: 300
content.html: 300

content.text: Random
Worst Case
Best Case
10 Random
Operations: 0
content.html: Operations: 0

content.text: For Insertion Sort, there is a big difference between best, average and worst case scenarios. You can see that by running the different simulations above.
content.html: For Insertion Sort, there is a big difference between best, average and worst case scenarios. You can see that by running the different simulations above.

content.text: The red line above represents the theoretical upper bound time complexity O ( n 2 ) O ( n 2 ) , and the actual function in this case is 1.07 ⋅ n 2 1.07 ⋅ n 2 .
content.html: The red line above represents the theoretical upper bound time complexity O(n2)O(n2), and the actual function in this case is 1.07⋅n21.07⋅n2.

content.text: Remember that a function f ( n ) f ( n ) is said to be O ( g ( n ) ) O ( g ( n ) ) if we have a positive constant C C so that C ⋅ g ( n ) > f ( n ) C ⋅ g ( n ) > f ( n ) .
content.html: Remember that a function f(n)f(n) is said to be O(g(n))O(g(n)) if we have a positive constant CC so that C⋅g(n)>f(n)C⋅g(n)>f(n).

content.text: In this case f ( n ) f ( n ) is the number of operations used by Insertion Sort, g ( n ) = n 2 g ( n ) = n 2 and C = 1.07 C = 1.07 .
content.html: In this case f(n)f(n) is the number of operations used by Insertion Sort, g(n)=n2g(n)=n2 and C=1.07C=1.07.
